metadata.ttm:title: Being a Good Steward of your Digital Certificate
metadata.ttm:desc: Being a good steward of Digital Certificates means taking proper security measures with active Certificates, and also knowing when to revoke a Certificate, as might be necessary when an individual retires or changes jobs. This video reviews your responsibilities to maintining Digital Certificates in good faith.

div.p: Your digital certificate is essentially an
electronic credential stored on the web browser
that verifies your identity.
As such, it is important to be a good steward of
your digital certificate and observe best practices
in its use.
In this video we will cover backing up a
certificate, passwords, what to do on shared work
stations and when to revoke a digital
certificate.
It is highly recommended that you create a back up
copy of your certificate, and store it offline in a
safe place, such as a stick drive or writable
DVD, such as you would with ANY of your important
files.
In the event of a computer crash, this backup could
prove invaluable.
To make a backup of your certificate, open your web
browser, in this example we're using Internet
Explorer.
Open the "Tools" menu and select "Internet Options."
Click the "Content" tab, then the "Certificates
button."
From the "Personal", tab, click "Export" to start
the export wizard and follow the instructions to
export your certificate.
This is a brief overview of the process, more
details and instructions for other browsers are
provided in our videos on "Exporting a Certificate."
In submitting your application, you entered a
password for the digital certificate.
It is absolutely essential that you do not Forget
Your Password!
If you lose your password neither GSA nor your cert
provider can recover the password for you and you
will have to go through the process of purchasing
a new certificate all over again.
Write it down in a safe place and do not lose it.
If you share your computer with others, it is
important to enable strong private key protection
when you import your key.
For more information watch the video on importing a
digital certificate.
Enabling strong private key protection will
require users to enter their password every time
their certificate is verified when logging into
eOffer or eMod.
This will help ensure that no one is misusing your
digital certificate, intentionally or not.
Also make sure you do not leave your computer
unattended and that you log out of eOffer and eMod
when you are finished with either system.
There may be instances in which it is necessary to
revoke your or an employee's digital
certificate.
When for example an employee leaves your
company or you feel that your digital certificate's
security has been compromised.
An employee's digital certificate is tied
directly to your business.
If an employee leaves your company, even on friendly
terms, it is advised to have his or her
certificate revoked so they no longer have the
ability to represent your business.
You should first ensure they are removed as a
negotiator on any contracts they are
involved with.
You should then get in touch with the respective
digital certificate provider and ensure the
certificate is revoked.
Also a situation may arise where you think your key
has been compromised or you think someone has
access to your digital certificate.
You will need to get in touch with your digital
cert provider.
This may entail you having to purchase another
digital certificate.
Good stewardship is important throughout the
lifecycle of your digital certificate.
Best practices will keep your identity safe and
secure.
